ratings.comment: Very knowledgable, approachable, and fair. She made the class fun and interesting.

Gives you lecture slides to make it easier to study for exams. Caring person and gives good and effective feedback. Not the worst grader compared to others and is a reasonable grader. Doesn't give that many assignments.

I have an idea as to why there's bad reviews. She's a WOC in a PWI. She's the only professor I've had that made me feel safe. Very understanding and caring. I see people saying she talks a lot but I want to know which business professor doesn't speak for the full lecture time? The problem I saw is that nobody ever participated so she had no choice.
I'm still taking this course. I personally cannot believe one individual is able to talk for so long. Merlins Beard!!

Min Li is on a mission to convince you that MHR is much more difficult than it is. She is a nice person and the structure of lectures and work is fine. Only four students in my class received A's, which is unnecessarily low. I believe she does this to make a point. Don't take this class with Min Li. She makes it way harder than it needs to be.

Just take a different professor. She made this class much more stressful/frustrating compared to conventionally hard classes. Don't know how she thinks her lectures will make us passionate about management. Expects you to reread the textbook before every exam.

Simply just take another professor. The exams have a ridiculous time constraint for the amount of questions. She is very caring about her students and is accessible outside of class, but she makes such a easy topic way too hard. VERY hard to get an A.

Min seems to care for her students but puts an unreasonable amount of work and stress on them. The workload is hefty and graded harshly. If you're an MHR major and/or looking for an MHR elective, I highly suggest avoiding this professor because it will be just as hard as a 300-level course. Good luck getting an A with this professor.

Min Li was a very kind and nice professor, however her ability to fairly grade is very concerning. I received such low grades on my projects and papers that I question her ability to understand how fair grading works. The class isn't hard by any means, but if you have to take this class I would strongly suggest finding a different teacher for it.

Professor Li is one of the most genuine professors I have had at UW. She really cares about students and works quite hard to make the classwork as useful as possible. MHR300 is unfortunately, a required and sad class, but MHR403 which is taught solely by Professor Li showed how strong she is as a Professor!

Min is a very nice and caring person but not a great teacher. Everything is based on the textbook. Exam questions are all nit picky specific from the textbook. Little lecture content/discussion stuff is tested, mainly just the textbook. Plenty of busy work with different due dates/times that can get tricky to keep track of it all. Not the best.

Min has never held a real management job in her life and it shows in her teaching. Classic academic who doesn't have any real world experience to draw from. Exams are incredibly nit picky and require you to remember minute details from the text. She is a nice person, but I'd rather learn from a businessperson than from her and her 4 or so degrees.

Min is a great professor and I can tell she actually cares about her students. She does expect you to read the book and study the material outside of lecture but she is very organized and has clear expectations. I had fun in her class & would recommend.

Had Prof Min for 403 before 300 & although the material is pretty bland for 300, I felt she did a great job; truly tried her best to engage students. 300 is a blended class which may b y some students feel it's disorganized but Min is one of the MOST organized profs I have ever had. Just reading, weekly quizzes, 1 group project, 1 midterm. Easy A.

Min Li is a nice person but a bad professor. I don't know if she creates the structure of the course, but it is the most disorganized and useless class structure. (pretty dumb considering the class is about management and utilizing human capital). The tests are multiple choice but answers are subjective. learned nothing, had no idea how to get an A

Took this class as a freshman not having any MHR background and it wasn't bad. Min is so sweet too. Def lecture & book heavy though, activities in class will be referenced on exams! As long as you learn the study guide you'll be fine, no trick questions either. Only has 2 case studies,1 group project, 1 midterm, and a noncumulative exam. Just read
Exams based only on how well you can memorize the textbook, ruined interesting content with very dry exams

I feel Professor Li and the MHR300 class at UW needs to be separated. MHR300 isn't great in general across the board. I had the pleasure to have Min for my MHR403 class that I took for business breadth and her lectures were amazing and her teaching style really came alive. I recommend her as a professor to anyone and recommend her MHR403 class.

Min really cares about the subject, but the structure of the class makes it hard to be engaged sometimes because it is half online. She doesn't have any industry experience, but she still knows so much! There is 1 midterm, 1 final, 1 large group project, and online activities. The best way to study for exams is from the textbook!!

Min Li is really a nice lady. However, she has no experience in the industry- she went right from school to teaching. Her grading criteria is not clear at all on the one main project. This class should be completely online with just exams in person. Good luck on her exams, you basically need to memorize the entire book.

She cares about the students and encourages active engagement, but the grading is exceptionally difficult and the tests test you on extremely specific details in the book. This is not a class I recommend taking.

Really works hard to get students involved. Knows her stuff and wants to help students. Don't expect to show up and get full participation points. Actually requires engagement and expects you to be able to discuss readings, cases, etc. in class.

Min isn't as bad of a prof as she gets a rep for, it's really just the class that sucks. Min is enthusiastic about very boring material and encourages class discussion. However, MHR 300 is just a boring, disorganized class that you just have to check off the box. so as far as the class goes, she does a good job.

Min is very unclear professor and makes many judgement calls regarding grading. For example, your group project which is worth more than the exam has 3 sentences for a rubric. She expects you to know what she wants. She also has no real world experience which makes memorizing her information pointless. I would recommend to avoid if you can.

Min is a career professor; she went straight from school to teaching without gaining experience in the business world. Therefore, she teaches facts that she does not  understand without having any personal examples to back them up and is uninspiring. Her exams are widely specified and so hard that a 60% gave you a B. Avoid at all costs.
